awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Neogene fruits and seeds from the Gray Fossil Site, Tennessee: Using multiple imaging techniques to clarify an obscure interval in the history of Appalachian vegetation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will analyze the fossilized fruits and seeds from the Gray Fossil Site located in eastern Tennessee. Ongoing excavation of the site, an ancient sinkhole deposit discovered in 2000, has yielded numerous, well-preserved fossils of terrestrial plants and animals that lived approximately seven to four-and-a-half million years ago. The vegetation of this time period in the Appalachian region is significant because it predates the widespread ecological disturbance caused by Pleistocene-age environmental changes, yet its biodiversity is not well understood. Consequently, the Gray Fossil Site presents a unique opportunity to clarify how ecosystems of the Appalachian region have changed over recent geological history. Researchers will identify species of fossil fruits and seeds from the site and will describe those new to science. They will then compare the diversity of fossil plant species found at the site to that of other ancient and modern plants world-wide. The comparison may provide transformative insights regarding the pace of biological diversification, extinction, and geographic range shifts of plant species at a local to global scale. Researchers will train undergraduate students and engage the public at the Gray Fossil Site and Museum by producing a digital visitor's guide to the fossil flora. Research results will be disseminated widely and will include contributions to the NSF-funded, open access Digital Atlas of Ancient Life.

This project will create the first comprehensive carpoflora for the Gray Fossil Site. Researchers will analyze previously excavated fruit and seed fossils using a combination of light microscopy, scanning electron microscopy and micro-computed tomography. These methods supply complementary data that characterize both surface morphological and internal anatomical details without the need for destructive dissection. Project personnel will determine the systematic affinities of the fossils using structural characteristics and phylogenetic analyses, where feasible. They will then assess the biogeographic relationships of the carpoflora based on the taxonomy of the fossils. These data will test the hypothesis that the carpoflora will share greatest similarities to the ancient and modern floras of Eurasia and North America. Outcomes of this project will include an improved understanding of Miocene and Pliocene ecosystems of North America, the historical biogeography of the Appalachian flora, and the state of internal anatomical preservation of the Gray Fossil Site carpoflora. The project will improve the curation of US fossil collections and strengthen research collaborations among US institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this grant was to explore the diversity of the Gray Fossil Site macrofossil flora. Gray Fossil Site is located in Gray, eastern Tennessee, U.S.A. The site yields vertebrate, plant, and other fossils thought to date to the early Pliocene epoch (about 4.9 to 4.5 million years ago) that were preserved in a pond or lake. The flora of Gray Fossil Site is important because it is one of few plant macrofossil localities of Neogene age (the Neogene is a period spanning about 23.3 to 2.6 million years ago) from eastern North America outside of the Gulf Coastal Plain, and the only one from the southern Appalachian Mountains. Thus, documenting the Gray Fossil Site fossil flora is a vital part of understanding the diversity and evolution of plants in eastern North America during the Cenozoic Era (an era spanning the most recent 66 million years of Earth history), as well as understanding the diversity, distribution, and geography of plants throughout the northern hemisphere today.

Plant macrofossils at Gray Fossil Site include fruits, seeds, endocarps ("pits" or "stones" of drupes), and other structures, like stems and thorns. As a result of this project, more is now understood about the diversity of the site overall. Three new species of fossil plants were described in detail, including Cavilignum pratchettii endocarps (affinities unclear), Corylopsis grisea seeds (a type of winter hazel, a plant in Hamamelidaceae, the witch hazel family), and Passiflora appalachiana seeds (a type of passionflower). In addition, the identities of some plants previously identified in the flora by other investigators were confirmed, for example, knotweed fruits (cf. Persicaria) and raspberry endocarps (Rubus). Other structures were newly identified or preliminarily identified, such as a fossil wood-decaying fungal bodies (cf. Annulohypoxylon, Xylariaceae) and possible cockleburs (cf. Xanthium).

The results of this project confirmed a previous observation about the Gray Fossil Site flora and presented new biogeographical data. Notably, the presence of winter hazel (Corylopsis) in the fossil flora reinforced the already recognized occurrence of plants found today in eastern Asia but now extinct in North America at Gray Fossil Site; these North American extinctions were perhaps caused by cooling during the Pleistocene "Ice Ages" (about 2.6 million to 11,700 years ago). Cavilignum pratchettii is the first extinct plant from Gray Fossil Site that has no clear fossil or modern relatives. The Gray Fossil Site passionflower (Passiflora appalachiana) is similar to the modern southeastern native maypop (Passiflora incarnata) and provides a link to the modern flora of the southeastern U.S.; it is also the first plant macrofossil species described from the site that has a biogeographic link to the neotropics, which have the highest diversity of passionflowers today. Continuing work on a second species of passionflower from Gray Fossil Site reinforces the unexpected neotropical connection.

Findings have been shared in scientific publications, in virtual and in-person presentations at scientific meetings, and through in-person and virtual presentations and interviews for the public. Publications on the Gray Fossil Site macrofossil flora supported by this award include two papers coauthored by student or beginning researchers.

In addition to the work on the Gray Fossil Site macrofossil flora, pages were added to the Embryophytes (https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/learn/embryophytes/) and Paleoclimate Estimation with Plant Fossils (https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/learn/paleoecology/paleoclimate/) sections of the online, open-access Digital Encyclopedia of Ancient Life (https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/learn/). The PI also completed or coauthored several other research publications on fossil plants.
